claims_to_validate.claim_text: The current Bayzat payroll system lacks automated salary calculation based on precise working days. The platform cannot dynamically adjust salaries proportionally when employees work more or fewer than the standard 26 working days.

The daily wage calculator in payroll settings intentionally overrides the formula configured in the leave policy for unpaid leave. The leave policy formula appears greyed out, indicating it is not active. This creates user confusion about which formula is actually being applied for daily wage calculations.

System failed to recalculate pending unpaid leave deductions when new salary configurations were created after leave request submission. Deductions were calculated based on previous salary configuration instead of current one, resulting in incorrect payroll deduction amount.
The End of Service (EOS) gratuity calculator incorrectly calculates service days by using 365 days instead of 366 days for 2024, resulting in an inaccurate total service period and gratuity amount.

End of Service (EOS) calculation is producing incorrect pro-rated amounts due to a rounding or decimal precision error. The daily wage formula (basic + allowances / 30) is configured correctly, but when calculating pro-rated EOS amounts, the system consistently shows amounts that are less than expected by 0.1 or 0.2 decimals.

System gratuity calculation showed slight difference from manual calculation (System: AED 231,821, Manual: AED 252,485). Detailed calculation breakdown revealed system uses specific service duration and daily wage formula with tiered rates (21 days per year for first 5 years, 30 days per year after 5 years).
The system's gratuity calculation may not transparently handle February 29th in leap years, causing minor discrepancies in total service days calculation (912 vs 913 days).

The daily wage calculator's gratuity calculation involves complex logic for handling partial years of service, especially for periods above 5 years. The system uses specific methodologies for calculating service duration, including leap year adjustments and day count segmentation.

Platform calculates total job tenure with a potential extra day (623 days vs expected 622 days). Daily wage calculation uses a fixed 30-day divisor, which differs from client's preferred method of (Basic × 12 / 365).

System calculates leave salary based on predefined policy configuration, which may not align with user expectations about calendar days and prorated calculations. Users may misunderstand how daily wage is divided (31 vs 30 days) and challenge the resulting prorated salary amount.

The daily wage calculator's 'working days' setting causes monthly fluctuations in leave salary accrual calculations. The daily wage rate changes based on the number of working days in each month, leading to inconsistent cumulative totals.
The system uses different divisors for leave salary and salary proration calculations. Leave salary uses a 30-day divisor while salary proration uses 30.42 days, causing calculation discrepancies.

User initially misunderstood how working days are calculated based on work week configuration. The system was actually calculating correctly, but the user did not initially understand that their specific work week (NVK Operations) had all 7 days configured as working days.

The system fails to correctly prorate salary when an employee's departure date is in the future relative to payroll processing date. Proration works correctly for past departure dates but not for future dates.

When an unpaid leave request is approved and transaction submitted, then the daily wage calculation is changed and the transaction deleted to recalculate, the system creates duplicate deductions—one with the old calculation and one with the new. Moving the leave request back to pending/accepted does not resolve the issue. Even after deleting the unpaid leave request entirely, the unpaid leave deduction persists in payroll deductions.

When public holidays are added after a leave request is created, the daily wage calculation becomes misaligned between the Time Off and Payroll modules. This causes incorrect salary deduction amounts due to a timing mismatch in working days calculation.
The system calculates unpaid leave deductions using a custom daily wage divisor (30.42 days) instead of calendar days, which can produce deduction amounts that differ from user expectations
The system displays incorrect number of days in remarks for February unpaid leave deduction - showing 31 days instead of 29 days, despite the underlying calculation being mathematically correct

The system uses a global daily rate configuration that overrides individual policy-specific unpaid leave calculation methods, potentially leading to incorrect salary deductions. The global configuration takes precedence over policy-level settings, calculating deductions using a system-wide daily rate instead of policy-defined methods.

The system displays the daily rate from the payroll processing month (May) instead of the leave occurrence month (April), causing user confusion. The actual deduction amount is calculated correctly, but the displayed daily rate is from the wrong month.
Salary is based on a standard 26 working days per month, calculated from 365 annual days minus 52 weekly offs, resulting in 313 working days per year divided by 12 months.
